verse.text: Paul, an Apostle of Christ Jesus through the will of God, and Timothy our brother, to the assembly of God that is in Corinth, along with all the consecrated ones throughout the whole of Achaia:
Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of mercies and the God of all strengthening encouragement,

who encourages us in all our crushing pressure, so that we may be able to encourage those in any kind of crushing pressure through the same strengthening encouragement with which we ourselves are encouraged by God.
For just as the sufferings of the Christ overflow into us, so through the Christ our strengthening encouragement overflows as well.

If we are under crushing pressure, it is for your strengthening encouragement and deliverance; if we are encouraged, it is for your strengthening encouragement, which is made effective in the patient endurance of the same sufferings that we also suffer.
Our hope for you is firm, knowing that as you are partners in the sufferings, so you are also partners in the strengthening encouragement.
For we do not want you to be ignorant, brothers, about the crushing pressure that came upon us in Asia: we were burdened so far beyond our strength that we despaired even of living.
In fact, we had the death sentence within ourselves, so that we would not trust in ourselves but in God, who raises the dead.
He rescued us from such a deadly peril and will rescue us; we have set our hope on him that he will continue to rescue us,
as you also join in helping us through your petition. Then, through the prayers of many people, the favor granted to us will result in many giving thanks on our behalf.

For this is our boast: the testimony of our conscience, that we have conducted ourselves in the world—and especially toward you—in the holiness and sincerity of God, not in fleshly wisdom but in the grace of God.
For we do not write anything to you other than what you read or even understand; and I hope you will understand until the end,
just as you have understood us in part—that we are your boast, just as you are ours, on the day of our Lord Jesus.
Confident in this, I intended to come to you first, so that you might have a second favor,
and to pass through you into Macedonia, and to come to you again from Macedonia and be sent on my way by you to Judea.
Since I intended this, I didn’t do it lightly, did I? Or do I make my plans according to the flesh, so that with me it is "Yes, yes" and "No, no" at the same time?
But as God is faithful, our word to you is not both "Yes" and "No."
For the Son of God, Jesus Christ, who was proclaimed among you through us—through me, Silvanus, and Timothy—did not become "Yes" and "No," but in him it has always been "Yes."
For every one of God’s promises finds its "Yes" in him. Therefore, through him, the "Amen" is spoken by us to the glory of God.
Now the one who confirms us with you into Christ and who anointed us is God,
who also sealed us and gave us the down payment of the Spirit in our hearts.
I call upon God as a witness against my own soul that it was to spare you that I did not come again to Corinth.
It is not that we lord it over your faith, but we are fellow-workers for your joy, for you stand firm in the faith.
I made this decision for my own sake: not to come to you in grief again.
For if I cause you grief, who is left to make me glad except the one I have grieved?
I wrote this very thing so that when I arrived, I would not be grieved by the very people who ought to make me rejoice. I have confidence in all of you that my joy belongs to all of you.
For out of much affliction and a constricted heart I wrote to you through many tears—not so that you would be grieved, but so that you might know the overflowing love I have for you.
Now if anyone has caused grief, he has not grieved me, but to some extent—not to overstate it—he has burdened all of you.
This disciplinary censure by the majority is sufficient for such a person.
So now, on the contrary, you should rather extend grace and comfort, so that such a person is not consumed by excessive grief.
Therefore I urge you to formally ratify your love for him.
I also wrote for this purpose: to see the proof of your character, whether you are obedient in everything.
Anyone you forgive, I also forgive. For what I have forgiven—if I have forgiven anything—I have done for your sake in the presence of Christ,
so that we might not be outmaneuvered by Satan; for we are not ignorant of his schemes.
When I came to Troas for the good news of Christ, even though a door was opened for me in the Lord,
I had no relief in my spirit because I did not find my brother Titus there. So I said my farewells to them and left for Macedonia.
But thanks be to God, who always leads us as captives in Christ’s triumphal procession, and through us spreads the fragrance of the knowledge of him in every place.
verse.note: During a Roman triumph, incense was burned throughout the city. To the victors and the cheering crowds, this scent meant "life" and celebration. To the captives being led in the parade, the same scent meant "death," as it signaled their approaching execution. This dual-meaning of the aroma perfectly captures Paul's description of the gospel's reception.

verse.text: For we are the sweet aroma of Christ to God, both among those who are being saved and among those who are perishing:
to the latter, a scent of death leading to death; to the former, a scent of life leading to life. And who is sufficient for these things?
For we are not like the many who huckster the word of God. On the contrary, we speak in Christ with sincerity, as those sent from God and standing in the presence of God.
Are we starting to recommend ourselves again? Or do we, like some people, need letters of introduction to you, or perhaps from you?
You yourselves are our letter, inscribed on our hearts, known and read by everyone.

You make it obvious that you are a letter from Christ, delivered through our service, inscribed not with ink but with the Spirit of the living God—not on tablets of stone, but on tablets of human hearts.
We have this kind of confidence toward God through Christ.
Not that we are competent in ourselves to claim anything as coming from us; rather, our competence comes from God.
He is the one who made us competent as servants of a new covenant—not of a written code, but of the Spirit. For the written code kills, but the Spirit gives life.

Now if the service that brought death, which was engraved in letters on stones, arrived with such radiance that the people of Israel could not gaze at the face of Moses because of its radiance (even though that radiance was already being deactivated),
how much more will the service of the Spirit be characterized by radiance?
For if the service of condemnation had its radiance, the service of justice overflows with radiance all the more!
In fact, what was once radiant has lost its radiance in this respect, because of the radiance that completely surpasses it.
For if what was being deactivated came through radiance, how much more does that which remains exist in radiance!
Since we have such a hope, we speak with great plainness.
We are not like Moses, who would put a veil over his face so that the people of Israel would not gaze at the final end of what was being deactivated.
But their minds were calloused. To this very day, that same veil remains whenever the old covenant is read. It is not lifted, because only in Christ is it deactivated.
Yes, to this day, whenever Moses is read, a veil lies over their hearts.
But whenever one turns to the Lord, the veil is stripped away.
Now the "Lord" is the Spirit, and where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is freedom.

And we all, with unveiled faces, contemplating the Lord’s radiance as in a mirror, are being transformed into that same image, from one degree of radiance to another, just as from the Lord, who is the Spirit.
Therefore, because we have this commission through the mercy shown to us, we do not lose heart.

Instead, we have renounced the shameful things hidden from view; we do not conduct ourselves with unprincipled cunning or tamper with the word of God. Rather, by the open demonstration of the truth, we present ourselves to every human conscience in the sight of God.
And even if our good news is veiled, it is veiled among those who are perishing.
In their case, the god of this current age has blinded the minds of those without faith, to keep them from seeing the light of the good news of the glory of Christ, who is the living image of God.
For we do not herald ourselves, but Christ Jesus as Lord, and ourselves as your slaves for the sake of Jesus.
For the God who said, “Light will shine out of darkness,” is the one who has shone in our hearts to bring to light the knowledge of the glory of God in the face of Christ.
But we have this treasure in earthenware jars, so that the extraordinary nature of the power may be from God and not from us.
We are hard-pressed in every way, but not crushed; we are at a loss, but not driven to despair;
we are persecuted, but not abandoned; we are struck down, but not destroyed.
We are always carrying around the dying of Jesus in our body, so that the life of Jesus may also be made visible in our body.
For we who live are constantly being handed over to death for Jesus’s sake, so that the life of Jesus may also be made visible in our mortal flesh.
So then, death is at work in us, but life is at work in you.
Since we have the same spirit of trust according to what is written—“I trusted, therefore I spoke”—we also trust, and therefore we speak.
We know that the one who raised the Lord Jesus will also raise us with Jesus and bring us into his presence along with you.
For all this is for your sake, so that as grace overflows through more and more people, it may cause thanksgiving to abound to the glory of God.
Therefore we do not lose heart. Though our outer self is wasting away, our inner self is being renewed day by day.
For this momentary, light pressure is producing for us an eternal weight of glory that is beyond all comparison.
We do not focus on the things that are seen, but on the things that are unseen; for the things that are seen are temporary, but the things that are unseen are eternal.
For we know that if the house of our earthly tent is torn down, we have a permanent building from God—a house not made by human hands, eternal in the heavens.
Indeed, in this tent we groan, longing to be further clothed with our dwelling from heaven,
since, having put it on, we will not be found naked.
For while we are in this tent, we groan under our burdens; it is not that we want to be stripped of our clothing, but rather to be clothed over, so that what is mortal may be swallowed up by life.
The one who has prepared us for this very purpose is God, who gave us the Spirit as a down payment.
Therefore, we are always confident. We know that while we are at home in the body, we are away from our home with the Lord—
for we walk by trust, not by what we see.
We are confident, I say, and would prefer to be away from the home of the body and to be at home with the Lord.
For this reason, we make it our ambition to be pleasing to him, whether we are at home or away.
For all of us must appear before the tribunal of the Christ, so that each may receive what is due for the things done through the body, whether good or worthless.
Therefore, because we know what it means to fear the Lord, we try to persuade people. What we are is plain to God, and I hope it is also plain to your consciences.

We are not recommending ourselves to you again, but are giving you an opportunity to take pride in us, so that you may have an answer for those who take pride in outward appearances and not in what is in the heart.
For if we were "out of our minds," it was for God; if we are of sound mind, it is for you.
For the love of Christ compels us, because we have concluded this: one died for all, therefore all died.
And he died for all so that those who live should no longer live for themselves, but for the one who died and was raised for them.
So then, from now on, we recognize no one according to the standards of the flesh. Even if we once recognized Christ according to the flesh, we no longer recognize him that way.
Therefore, if anyone is in Christ—new creation! The old things have passed away; look, new things have come into being.
All this is from God, who reconciled us to himself through Christ and gave us the ministry of reconciliation:
namely, that God was in Christ reconciling the world to himself, not counting their wrongdoings against them, and he has placed within us the word of reconciliation.
We are therefore acting as ambassadors on behalf of Christ, as though God were making his appeal through us. We plead on behalf of Christ: "Be reconciled to God!"
He made the one who did not know sin to be sin for us, so that in him we might become the justice of God.
Working together with God, we also appeal to you: do not receive the grace of God in a way that leads to nothing.
For he says: “At the favorable time I listened to you, and on the day of salvation I came to your aid.” Look! Now is the well-accepted time. Look! Now is the day of salvation.
We give no cause for offense in anything, so that our service may not be found at fault.
Instead, in every way we commend ourselves as servants of God: by great endurance, in afflictions, in hardships, in calamities,
in beatings, in imprisonments, in riots, in exhausting labors, in sleepless nights, in hunger;
by purity, by knowledge, by patience, by kindness, by the Holy Spirit, by genuine love,
by truthful speech, and by the power of God. We come with the weapons of justice in the right hand and in the left;
through glory and dishonor, through slander and good report. We are treated as deceivers, and yet we are true;
as unknown, and yet we are well known; as dying, and look! we live; as disciplined, and yet not put to death;
as sorrowing, yet always rejoicing; as poor, yet making many rich; as having nothing, yet possessing everything.
Our mouth has opened wide to you, Corinthians; our heart has been thrown wide open.
You are not being squeezed by us, but you are being squeezed in your own deepest feelings.
As a fair exchange—I speak to you as to my own children—open your hearts wide as well.
Do not be mismatched under a different yoke with those who do not believe. For what partnership is there between justice and lawlessness? Or what fellowship has light with darkness?
What harmony is there between Christ and Beliar? Or what share does a believer have with an unbeliever?

What agreement does the sanctuary of God have with idols? For we are the sanctuary of the living God, just as God said: “I will dwell among them and walk among them, and I will be their God, and they will be my people.
Therefore, come out from among them and be separate,” says the Lord, “and do not touch what is unclean; then I will receive you.
And I will be a Father to you, and you will be sons and daughters to me,” says the Lord, the All-Powerful.
Therefore, since we have these promises, beloved, let us scrub ourselves clean from every pollution of the flesh and the spirit, bringing holiness to its full expression in the fear of God.
Make room for us in your hearts. We have wronged no one, we have ruined no one, we have exploited no one.
I am not saying this to condemn you; for I have said before that you are in our hearts so deeply that we would die together or live together.
I have great confidence in you; I have great pride in you. I am filled to the brim with encouragement; I overflow with joy in the midst of all our affliction.
For even when we arrived in Macedonia, our human flesh found no relief. Instead, we were pressured at every turn—battles on the outside, fears on the inside.
But God, who encourages the downcast, encouraged us by the arrival of Titus.

And it was not only by his arrival, but also by the encouragement he received from you. He reported to us your deep longing, your mourning, and your burning zeal for me, so that I rejoiced all the more.
For even if I grieved you with my letter, I do not regret it—though I did regret it for a moment (for I see that the letter grieved you, even if only for a short time).

Now I rejoice, not because you were pained, but because your pain led to a change of heart. For you were grieved in accordance with God’s own character, so that you suffered no loss at our hands in any way.
For the grief that accords with God’s character produces a change of heart that leads to salvation—a path that brings no regret. But the grief of the world produces only death.

For look at this very thing—this grieving in accordance with God’s heart—what earnestness it has produced in you! What a defense of yourselves! What indignation! What fear! What longing! What zeal! What a redressing of wrong! In every way you have proven yourselves to be pure in this matter.

So, even though I wrote to you, it was not primarily for the sake of the one who did the wrong, nor for the sake of the one who was wronged, but so that your earnestness for us might be made plain to you in the sight of God.
Because of this, we have been encouraged. And in addition to our own encouragement, we rejoiced even more at the joy of Titus, because his spirit has been set at ease by all of you.
For if I have boasted to him at all about you, I have not been put to shame. But just as we spoke everything to you in truth, so also our boasting to Titus has proven to be the truth.
And his deepest affections go out to you even more as he remembers the obedience of you all, and how you received him with fear and trembling.
I rejoice that I can have complete confidence in you.[/SPEAKER]
Now we want you to know, brothers and sisters, about the act of grace God has given among the churches of Macedonia.
Even under a severe ordeal of affliction, the overflow of their joy and their deep, down-to-the-bottom poverty overflowed into the wealth of their sincere generosity.
I testify that they gave according to their ability—and even beyond their ability. Entirely of their own accord,
they begged us with much pleading for the favor of participating in this service to the holy ones.
And this was not merely as we had hoped; rather, they gave themselves first to the Lord and then to us through the will of God.
This led us to urge Titus that, just as he had started this work before, he should also complete this act of grace among you.
But just as you excel in everything—in trust, in speech, in knowledge, in all earnestness, and in the love we have sparked in you—see that you also excel in this act of grace.
I am not saying this as a command, but I am testing the genuineness of your love by comparison with the earnestness of others.
For you know the generosity of our Lord Jesus Christ: that for your sake he became poor, though he was wealthy, so that through his poverty you might become wealthy.
I am giving my opinion on this matter because it is to your advantage—you who began a year ago not only the doing but also the desiring.
Now, finish the doing as well, so that your readiness to desire it may be matched by the completion of it, based on what you have.
For if the readiness is there, the gift is acceptable according to what one has, not according to what one does not have.
This is not so that others may have relief while you have hardship, but as a matter of equity.
At the present time, your abundance meets their need, so that their abundance may also meet your need, so that there may be equity.
As it is written: “The one who gathered much did not have too much, and the one who gathered little did not have too little.”
But thanks be to God, who put the same earnestness for you into the heart of Titus.
For he not only welcomed our appeal, but being even more earnest, he is going out to you of his own accord.
And we have sent with him the brother whose praise in the gospel is known through all the churches.
Not only that, but he was also appointed by the churches to be our traveling companion in this act of grace which we are administering for the glory of the Lord himself and to show our readiness.
We are taking this precaution so that no one will find fault with us regarding this bountiful gift we are administering.
For we take thought for what is honorable, not only in the sight of the Lord but also in the sight of people.
We have also sent with them our brother whom we have often tested and found to be earnest in many things, but who is now much more earnest because of his great confidence in you.
As for Titus, he is my partner and fellow worker among you; as for our brothers, they are envoys of the churches, the glory of Christ.
Therefore, show them the proof of your love and of our boasting about you, in the presence of the churches.
Now, regarding the service to those who are set apart for God, it is truly unnecessary for me to keep writing to you.
For I know your eagerness, of which I boast on your behalf to the Macedonians, telling them that Achaia has been ready since last year; and your zeal has stirred up the majority of them.
But I am sending the brothers so that our boasting about you in this matter might not prove empty, but so that you may be prepared, just as I said you would be.
Otherwise, if any Macedonians come with me and find you unprepared, we—not to say you—would be put to shame in this confident undertaking.

Therefore, I thought it necessary to urge the brothers to go on ahead to you and arrange in advance this blessing-gift you previously promised, so that it might be ready as a genuine blessing and not as something extorted from your greed.
Consider this: the one who sows sparingly will also reap sparingly, and the one who sows upon the foundation of blessings will also reap upon the foundation of blessings.
Each person should give as they have determined in their heart, not out of regret or under compulsion; for God loves a cheerful giver.
And God is able to make every grace overflow to you, so that in every way, always having everything you need for contentment, you may overflow in every good work.
Just as it is written: “He scattered abroad, he gave to the poor; his justice endures forever.”
Now, the one who supplies seed to the sower and bread for food will supply and multiply your seed and will increase the harvest produced by your justice.
You will be enriched in every way for every kind of sincere generosity, which through us produces thanksgiving to God.
For the service of this public ministry is not only fully supplying the needs of the holy ones, but it is also overflowing through many thanksgivings to God.

Through the proof provided by this service, they will glorify God for the submissive loyalty of your confession to the Good News of the Christ, and for the sincerity of your partnership with them and with everyone.
And in their prayer for you, they long for you because of the surpassing grace of God upon you.
Thanks be to God for his indescribable gift!
Now I, Paul himself, appeal to you by the gentle strength and gracious forbearance of Christ—I who am supposedly "lowly" when face-to-face with you, but "bold" toward you when away!
I beg of you that when I am present, I may not have to be bold with that confidence with which I reckon I will dare to confront some who calculate that we are walking according to the flesh.
For though we walk in the flesh, we do not wage war according to the flesh.
For the weapons of our warfare are not fleshly, but divinely powerful for the tearing down of strongholds. We are tearing down mental schemes
and every lofty thing that raises itself up against the knowledge of God, and we are taking every thought captive to the obedience of Christ,
being ready to punish every act of disobedience as soon as your own obedience is made complete.
Look at the obvious facts before your face. If anyone has convinced himself that he belongs to Christ, let him calculate this again for himself: that just as he belongs to Christ, so also do we.
For even if I should boast somewhat more abundantly about our authority—which the Lord gave for building you up and not for tearing you down—I will not be put to shame.
I say this so I do not seem as if I am trying to terrify you through my letters.
For “His letters,” they say, “are weighty and forceful, but his physical presence is weak and his speech is worth nothing.”
Let such a person calculate this: that what we are in word through letters when absent, we will also be in deed when present.

For we do not dare to classify or compare ourselves with some of those who recommend themselves. But when they measure themselves by one another and compare themselves with one another, they show they have no understanding.
We, however, will not boast beyond our limits, but will stay within the limit of the boundary which God assigned to us as a measure—to reach even as far as you.
For we are not overextending ourselves as if we had not reached you, for we were the first to come all the way to you with the good news of Christ.
We do not boast beyond our limits in the labors of others, but we have the hope that as your faith increases, our influence among you will be greatly enlarged within our assigned boundary,
so that we may preach the good news to the regions beyond you, without boasting about work already prepared in someone else’s boundary.

text.q: “But let the one who boasts, boast in the Lord.”

verse.text: For it is not the one who recommends himself who is approved, but the one whom the Lord recommends.
I wish you would tolerate a little foolishness from me—but indeed, you are already tolerating me.
For I am jealous for you with a jealousy like God’s; for I betrothed you to one husband, to present you as a pure virgin to the Christ.
But I am afraid that somehow, as the serpent deceived Eve by his craftiness, your minds might be corrupted from the sincere and pure devotion to the Christ.

For if someone comes and proclaims another Jesus whom we did not proclaim, or if you receive a different spirit which you did not receive, or a different gospel which you did not accept, you tolerate it beautifully!
For I consider myself in no way inferior to these “super-apostles.”
Even if I am unskilled in public speaking, I am certainly not so in knowledge; indeed, in every way we have made this clear to you in all things.
Or did I commit a sin by humbling myself so that you might be exalted, because I announced the good news of God to you free of charge?
I robbed other assemblies by taking support from them to serve you.

And when I was present with you and was in need, I was not a dead weight to anyone; for the brothers who came from Macedonia filled up what I lacked. In everything I kept myself from being a burden to you, and I will continue to do so.
As the truth of Christ is in me, this boast will not be silenced regarding me in the regions of Achaia.
Why? Because I do not love you? God knows I do!
And what I am doing, I will continue to do, so that I may cut off the opportunity from those who want an opportunity to be regarded as our equals in the things they boast about.
For such men are false apostles, deceitful workers, masquerading as apostles of Christ.
And no wonder, for even Satan masquerades as a messenger of light.
It is no great thing, then, if his servants also masquerade as servants of justice; their end will be according to their deeds.
I say again, let no one think me a fool—but if you do, then accept me as a fool, so that I too may boast a little.
What I am saying in this confident boasting, “I am not saying according to the Lord’s way, but as if in foolishness.”
Since many are boasting according to human standards, I will boast too.
For you gladly tolerate fools, being so wise yourselves!
For you tolerate it if someone enslaves you, if someone devours you, if someone takes advantage of you, if someone puts on airs, if someone hits you in the face.
To my shame, I must say that we were too “weak” for that! But in whatever anyone else dares to boast—I am speaking in foolishness—I dare to boast also.
Are they Hebrews? So am I. Are they Israelites? So am I. Are they the seed of Abraham? So am I.
Are they servants of Christ?—I am speaking like I’ve lost my mind—I am more so: in far more labors, in far more imprisonments, in countless beatings, and often near death.
Five times I received from the Jews the forty lashes minus one.
verse.note: This refers to the Jewish legal practice of limiting corporal punishment to thirty-nine strokes to ensure the biblical limit of forty (Deuteronomy 25:3) was never accidentally exceeded.

verse.text: Three times I was beaten with rods, once I was stoned, three times I was shipwrecked, a night and a day I have spent adrift in the deep.

I have been on frequent journeys, in dangers from rivers, dangers from bandits, dangers from my own people, dangers from the Gentiles, dangers in the city, dangers in the wilderness, dangers at sea, dangers among false brothers;
in labor and toil, through many sleepless nights, in hunger and thirst, often without food, in cold and exposure.
Besides these external things, there is the daily pressure on me: my anxiety for all the assemblies.
Who is weak, and I am not weak? Who is led into sin, and I do not burn with indignation?
If it is necessary to boast, I will boast of the things that show my weakness.
The God and Father of the Lord Jesus—he who is blessed forever—knows that I am not lying.
In Damascus, the governor under King Aretas was guarding the city of the Damascenes in order to seize me,
but I was lowered in a wicker basket through a window in the wall and escaped his hands.
It is necessary to boast. While it is not beneficial, I will go on to visions and revelations from the Lord.
I know a man in Christ who, fourteen years ago—whether in the body I do not know, or outside the body I do not know, God knows—was snatched up as far as the third heaven.
And I know that this man—whether in the body or apart from the body I do not know, God knows—
was snatched into Paradise and heard inexpressible words that no human is permitted to speak.
On behalf of such a man I will boast, but on behalf of myself I will not boast, except in my weaknesses.
For if I should wish to boast, I will not be a fool, because I will be speaking the truth. But I refrain, so that no one might credit me with more than what they see in me or hear from me,

especially because of the extraordinary nature of these revelations. Therefore, so that I might not be too elated, a stake was given to me in my flesh, a messenger of Satan to beat me, so that I might not be too elated.
Three times I appealed to the Lord about this, that it might leave me.

But he has said to me, “My favor is enough for you; for power is completed in weakness.” Therefore, I will boast all the more gladly in my weaknesses, so that the power of Christ might spread its tent over me.
For this reason I am content with weaknesses, with insults, with catastrophes, with persecutions and difficulties, for the sake of Christ; for whenever I am weak, then I am powerful.
I have become a fool—you forced me to it! For I ought to have been commended by you. Indeed, I was in no way inferior to these “super-apostles,” even if I am nothing.
The signs of the apostle were produced among you with total endurance, by signs and wonders and acts of power.
For in what way were you treated as inferior to the rest of the churches, except that I myself did not become a dead weight to you? Forgive me this injustice!

Look, for this third time I am ready to come to you, and I will not be a dead weight; for I do not seek what is yours, but you. For children ought not to save up for their parents, but parents for their children.
I will most gladly spend and be utterly spent for the sake of your souls. If I love you more abundantly, am I to be loved less?
But let it be; I did not weigh you down. Yet, being “crafty,” did I “trap you with a trick”?
Did I take advantage of you through any of those I sent to you?
I urged Titus to go and I sent the brother with him; Titus did not take advantage of you, did he? Did we not walk in the same spirit? In the same tracks?
Have you been thinking all this time that we are defending ourselves to you? We are speaking before God in Christ. Everything we do, beloved, is for your building up.

For I am afraid that perhaps when I come I may not find you such as I wish, and I may be found by you such as you do not wish—that there may perhaps be strife, jealousy, outbursts of anger, selfish rivalries, slanders, gossip, puffs of pride, and disorders.

I am afraid that when I come again my God may humble me before you, and I will have to mourn many of those who previously sinned and have not repented of the impurity, sexual immorality, and debauchery which they practiced.
This is the third time I am coming to you. “By the mouth of two or three witnesses every matter shall be established.”

I have warned you before, and I give warning now—as I did when present the second time, so also now while absent—to those who have sinned previously and to all the rest: if I come again, I will not be lenient,
since you are looking for proof that Christ is speaking in me. He is not weak in his dealings with you, but is powerful among you.
For indeed, he was crucified out of weakness, yet he lives by the power of God. For we also are weak in him, but we will live with him by the power of God for your benefit.

Examine yourselves to see if you are in the faith; test yourselves to prove your own genuineness. Or do you not recognize this about yourselves—that Jesus Christ is in you? Unless, of course, you fail the test.
And I hope you will realize that we do not fail the test.
But we pray to God that you do nothing wrong—not so that we may appear to have passed the test, but so that you may do what is right, even if we should appear to have failed.
For we have no power against the truth, but only on behalf of the truth.
For we rejoice when we are weak and you are strong. This is also what we pray for: your complete restoration.

This is why I write these things while absent, so that when I am present I may not have to act with severity, according to the authority the Lord gave me—an authority for building up and not for tearing down.
Finally, brothers and sisters, rejoice. Be restored, be encouraged, be of one mind, live in peace; and the God of love and peace will be with you.
Greet one another with a holy kiss. All the set-apart people send you their greetings.
The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ, the love of God, and the shared participation in the Holy Spirit be with you all.
